title: Benign Positional Vertigo Treatment
author: WebMD Editorial Contributors

sections.heading: Call 911 if the person loses consciousness or has:
bullets: Has non-stop vomiting
Cannot stand or walk due to dizziness

Has symptoms inconsistent with benign positional vertigo including: A head injury Convulsions Loss of consciousness Fever Headache or stiff neck Signs of stroke including change in vision , speech or moibility

sections.heading: 1. Relieve or Prevent Dizziness
bullets: Have the person lie down and rest.
The person should avoid sudden changes in body position.
Help the person avoid abrupt head movements, especially looking up.

items: Have the person lie down and rest.
The person should avoid sudden changes in body position.
Help the person avoid abrupt head movements, especially looking up.

sections.heading: 2. Keep the Person Safe
bullets: Help the person avoid falls.
If they are nauseous or throwing up, have them lie down on their side.
The person should not drive or operate dangerous machinery.
If they cannot walk safely, take them to the emergency room or call 911.

sections.heading: 3. Call a Health Care Provider
bullets: Any new signs and symptoms of vertigo should be checked by a health care provider.

items: Any new signs and symptoms of vertigo should be checked by a health care provider.

sections.heading: 4. Follow Up
bullets: The health care provider will do a focused physical exam that will include the parts of the neurological exam that focus on balance and the inner ear . This exam may include hearing and balance tests, and possibly a CT or MRI scan.

The most common and effective treatment is called particle repositioning maneuvers ( Epley maneuver ). A form of physical therapy for the inner ear, it can be done in outpatient setting and continued at home.

meta_description: Benign positional vertigo (BPV) -- or simply vertigo -- is a disorder of the inner ear. WebMD explains first aid steps in case of loss of consciousness.
